page.title: 01PRINCIPAL FEATURES
page.content: The area lies on the eastern edge of Kirklees which is one of the new names which appeared on the map when local government was reorganised in 1974. Kirklees is an area of nearly 160 square miles stretching from the Peak District{National Park}and the slopes of the South Pennines eastwards into the heavy woollen areas of Batley and Dewsbury. Our land is at its highest in the SW(122m) of the rectangle, and slopes down to a wide valley bottom (30m) which is dominated by the River Calder and the Calder and Hebble Navigation canal. The land then rises to the NE (80m). The land use in the area is mainly{housing}in the SW and NE with{farmland}inbetween in the valley bottom. There is an extensive sewage sewage works in the NW and a large {railway}marshaling yard in the SE.
